- start Eclipse
- File -> New -> Plug-in Project -> RCP App -> Hello World
- in the manifest, click on "Launch an Eclipse application"

You will get the following log file attach to the end of this report.

Note that there are 21 plug-ins selected in the "Plug-ins" tab of the Launch Configuration. When I start with -console -noexit and check, only 3 plug-ins are installed.

I was able to reproduce the problem.  It seems when you create a launch configuration by clicking the link in the Manifest Editor, the launch configuration is set up to a subset of all plug-ins.  This set does not include org.eclipse.update.configurator, which seems to be the culprit.  The work around for right now is to open up the launch configuration, click the Plug-ins tab, scroll down in the plug-ins table, and check the org.eclipse.update.configurator.  This should allow you to launch the application.  Please see if that works.
I have verified that adding the update.configurator to my launch config allows my application to launch.

Go figure, I broke it with some config.ini updates.  

It seems if we generated the config.ini file, we did a check to see if org.eclipse.update.configurator was included in the launch.  If not, we would then put all the plug-ins in osgi.bundles.  

With the changes, we rarely ever generate a config.ini file from nothing (we now use the target's config.ini when the user chooses to "generate" a config.ini).  Since properties that came from a template don't check for the org.eclipse.update.configurator case, it doesn't put all the bundles in osgi.bundles and is therefore failing.

I will go back and modify the logic to run the check of org.eclipse.update.configurator when we read properties from a template file.

I dropped a fix for org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.laucher.LaunchConfigurationHelper v1.20 to always parse osgi.bundles (whether generated or from a template) and check for org.eclipse.update.configurator and any necessary action.  Should be fixed in 3.3M5 (and next I-build).

After talking with Wassim (and his iron fist), I changed the logic slightly when computing the config.ini file.

In the original fix, we parse/recomputed the osgi.bundles tag if it was present in a user specified template.  With the latest change, we no longer do this.  We now only parse/recompute the osgi.bundles tag if we are generating the config.ini or if the tag is not present in the user's template(bug 161265).

Brian, just to be clear:

when the user supplies a template config.ini that contains an osgi.bundles key, you are not supposed to add/remove bundles from the list in it.  BUT, you are still supposed to substitute in absolute paths for the plug-ins listed in it.
Right, we strip the path information (as before) but do not go any further (ie. check to see if org.eclipse.update.configurator is included).
*** Bug 171663 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
